SENT.plain: The effect of middle cerebral artery (MCA) thrombosis on the integrity of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) was studied in rats using horseradish peroxidase (HRP)

Endothelial injury with subsequent platelet thrombosis was produced by means of a rose bengal-sensitized photochemical reaction, facilitated by irradiating the right proximal MCA segment with the focused beam of an argon laser
At 15 minutes following thrombosis formation, diffuse leakage of HRP was observed bilaterally within cortical and subcortical brain areas
Peroxidase extravasation was most dense within the territory of the occluded artery including neocortical areas and dorso-lateral striatum
Contralaterally, a similar distribution was observed but with less intense HRP leakage
Ultrastructural studies demonstrated an increase in permeability to HRP within arterioles, venules and capillaries
At these sites, the vascular endothelium contained HRP-filled pinocytotic vesicles and tubular profiles
Although less intense, bilateral HRP leakage was also observed following MCA stenosis or femoral artery occlusion
Endothelial-platelet interactions at the site of vascular injury may be responsible for releasing substances or neurohumoral factors which contribute to the acute opening of the BBB
